questions.question_text:
An organization's mobile device inventory recently provided notification that a zero-day vulnerability was identified in the code used to control the baseband of the devices. The device manufacturer is expediting a patch, but the rollout will take several months.
Additionally, several mobile users recently returned from an overseas trip and report their phones now contain unknown applications, slowing device performance.
Users have been unable to uninstall these applications, which persist after wiping the devices. Which of the following MOST likely occurred and provides mitigation until the patches are released?

choices.A: Unauthentic firmware was installed; disable OTA updates and carrier roaming via MDM
choices.D: Users received an improperly encoded emergency broadcast message, leading to an integrity loss condition; disable emergency broadcast messages
choices.C: An attacker downloaded monitoring applications; perform a full factory reset of the affected devices
choices.B: Users opened a spear-phishing email; disable third-party application stores and validate all signed code prior to execution

discussion.content:
A. There are several related questions like this. CompTIA really wants you to know 
Over-the-air updates and firmware attacks.

Maybe: C. An attacker downloaded monitoring applications; perform a full factory reset of the affected devices? Note: "phones now contain unknown applications, slowing device performance." This seems like the phones are being monitored - some sort of spyware. 
I like the mitigation offered with this option: full factory reset. Disabling OTA updates is not going to fix anything. There is some kind of malware on the phone, and the way to reliably get rid of it is to "nuke it from space."

questions.question_text:
A developer has executed code for a website that allows users to search for employees' phone numbers by last name. The query string sent by the browser is as follows: http://www.companywebsite.com/search.php?q=SMITH
The developer has implemented a well-known JavaScript sanitization library and stored procedures, but a penetration test shows the website is vulnerable to XSS.
Which of the following should the developer implement NEXT to prevent XSS? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: its secure cookies and output encoding.

comments.content: What do you consider to be the correct answers?
secure cookie and httponly are not the same thing. Secure cookie nothing to do with XSS

Maybe: B. Secure cookies? 
OWASP: Cross Site Scripting Prevention Cheat Sheet
Bonus Rule #1: Use HTTPOnly cookie flag¶
Preventing all XSS flaws in an application is hard, as you can see. To help mitigate the impact of an XSS flaw on your site, OWASP also recommends you set the HTTPOnly flag on your session cookie and any custom cookies you have that are not accessed by any JavaScript you wrote. This cookie flag is typically on by default in .NET apps, but in other languages you have to set it manually. For more details on the HTTPOnly cookie flag, including what it does, and how to use it, see the OWASP article on HTTPOnly.
https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Cross_Site_Scripting_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet.html

discussion.content: A sanitization library is already being used: "The developer has implemented a well-known JavaScript sanitization library." Doesn't this make 'A' redundant?

comments.content: You have a key 1, and you have pin 2. 2FA??

discussion.content:
Answer is B?

A. Facial recognition - invasive to the end user.
B. Swipe pattern - Meets 2FA (have key and know pattern) and has a low false acceptance rate.
C. Fingerprint scanning - invasive to the end user.
D. Complex passcode - Information sharing isn't avoided
E. Token card - Does not meet 2FA because you have a key and you have a token card.

Maybe: B. Swipe pattern ?
Fingerprint scanning be considered invasive

✑ It cannot be invasive to the end user.
✑ It must be utilized as a second factor.
✑ Information sharing must be avoided.

Which of the following BEST meets the criteria?
